awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Community Sourcing Introductory Physics for the Life Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
The Introductory Physics for Life Science (IPLS) Portal will enhance the education of hundreds of thousands of life science students each year by providing engaging and effective IPLS instructional materials and helping IPLS instructors use these materials. This collaborative effort of the American Association of Physics Teachers and eight colleges and universities, including a community college and a Hispanic-serving institution, will create an open-source, peer-reviewed, and innovatively structured environment for IPLS content. Initially containing materials from multiple NSF-funded research and development projects, the Portal will become a development platform for IPLS curricula. The site will serve as both an archive and a dissemination tool, including a course-building interface for faculty. Instructors will be supported in creating innovative and individualized courses, mixing and matching from multiple sources tuned to their needs, offering a flexible and low-cost alternative to traditional textbooks.  

Many of the objectives and features of the project are innovative.  Hence, the project also includes research components of four critical and interacting elements: IPLS content, IPLS pedagogy, the organizational structure of the site, including tagging and taxonomy of all elements for appropriate selection to meet the needs of individual users, and the user interface. Three overlapping research teams will carry out this work: the User-Centered Design team, the Instructional Content Design team, and the Community-Building and Professional-Development team. This project focuses on engaging and expanding three communities: (1) physics and biology education researchers, (2) IPLS contributors, and (3) IPLS adopters wanting to use and adapt existing IPLS materials.  Merging and expanding the efforts of these communities will occur through a combination of workshops, online support communities, and research to advance the understanding of faculty professional development for IPLS education. The IPLS-Portal infrastructure, once developed, could be used to provide a community-sourcing environment for other STEM disciplines.

por.por_cntn:
The Living Physics Portal (www.livingphysicsportal.org) is a collaboratively designed resource for curriculum and community. 

The Living Physics Portal is an online, open-source, innovative, web-based environment to support physics faculty in finding, sharing, and adapting curricular materials for introductory physics for life sciences (IPLS) courses and intermediate-level interdisciplinary physics courses. The Portal seeks to improve the education of the next generation of medical professionals and biologists by making physics classes more engaging and relevant for life science and health science students. The Portal is both a repository of curriculum materials and an environment for educators' community engagement.

The American Association of Physics Teachers (AAPT) led this project, along with 7 universities and colleges. The University of Maryland (UMD) helped design the Portal, contributed curricular materials (400+ problems), developed an open-source wiki-book, and led the community building activities and research effort. 

How was the Living Physics Portal designed to mutually support curriculum sharing and community building?

The Portal was developed through a user-centered design process. Extensive user research ensured that the Portal was designed based on needs of potential users and a strong understanding of their institutional environments. Each feature of the site was iteratively tested with potential users and refined based on their feedback. 

We designed the Portal to be a place where users can quickly and easily find relevant curricular materials from the grain-size of a homework problem or in-class activity, to a module or an entire course. We also designed the Portal for faculty to adapt curricular materials and reshare them, supporting intellectual exchange among users. 

The Portal interface makes it easy for users to contribute teaching materials they have designed themselves and share their pedagogical reasoning behind the materials. Faculty can share their curricular materials on the Portal in two different "libraries.?" In the Community Library, any verified educator can quickly and easily share their teaching materials and get feedback from other educators. Educators can also choose to submit their teaching materials to the Vetted Library where they provide more information about the pedagogical reasoning behind their materials and instructional approach. Vetted Library materials are reviewed by an editorial board and iteratively improved through feedback from the editorial team. 

In addition to sharing and finding materials, educators can participate in the Portal community in many ways. These include face-to-face workshops and synchronous online community activities, deliberately designed to cultivate an instructional community that uses the Portal tools to refine their practice. Our team recognized that to grow an instructional community, we would need to support people in collaborating, co-constructing meaning, and engaging in collective action. Within strong communities, community members can make well-justified assumptions about shared interests and overlapping values among the community members without deep personal knowledge of the individuals. Our Portal project team saw the need to deliberately design and run community activities around these online tools in order to cultivate and deepen these shared interests of users. Such community activities would be critical to users experiencing a sense of community and professional growth. The Portal is designed to support faculty learning about pedagogy in both curricular materials and the community by scaffolding conversations about instruction.

What impacts has The Living Physics Portal had? 

Broader Impacts: We designed, developed, and released (in beta) the Living Physics Portal. In conjunction, we developed community activities to engage physics instructors in developing and sharing expertise and curricular materials. The Portal website and community mutually support each other. In its short life thus far, the Portal is having an impact, with 642 registered users, 394 curricular contributions, and more than 2700 downloads. Additionally, 46 educators participated in 12 extended, synchronous online working groups and 62 educators participated in seven different workshops. If we conservatively estimate that each faculty member teaches approximately 80 students per year, the project has likely impacted as many as 150,000 students.


Intellectual Merit: This project brought together contributors from 11 prior NSF grants for developing interdisciplinary instructional materials, whose materials are now being effectively disseminated on the Portal. The Portal was developed through a user-centered design process including research to determine user needs around curricular design, organization of course materials, and community building, and iterative usability testing and refinement of each site feature. The Portal provides a model of an open and flexible community-sourced development and distribution environment for instructional materials, which could be expanded to other disciplines. The Portal team has given 50+ talks, offered 7 workshops featuring the Portal, and facilitated 10 online working groups. UMD contributed ~140 instructional resources to the Portal (including 400+ problems). Our team has published 12 articles and conference proceedings. This model has been successfully copied to create the Energy and Equity Portal, and an additional seven teams have connected our team with interest in using this model in other areas of physics and beyond.
